9.77.text: My name is Millie. I am 10 years old.

13.10.text: This is me when I am 3 years old. I love to play and dance.

17.78.text: I have been coming to hospital for a long time

20.96.text: after Mummy told me I was born with a big tummy.

23.76.text: I am afraid the results are conclusive.

29.47.text: That's a type of neurodegenerative disease

33.11.text: which means that Millie will start to decline both mentally and physically eventually.

41.28.text: Jesus we have been passed from pillar to post for years, and now -

45.24.text: It can't be true. He's wrong isn't he?

50.58.text: Of course, you may have as many opinions as you like and I'll help organise that for you

55.40.text: but I have to say, I think the results will all be the same.

64.89.text: They say there isn't much wrong with me. It's nothing bad.

68.63.text: They have done lots of tests, and now they know what is making my tummy so big.

74.92.text: Everyone is really nice to me at the hospital.

78.70.text: Mummy cried that day. So did Daddy.

82.50.text: I don't know why. Daddy never cries.

85.38.text: Mummy says he's not crying, he's laughing. It's a strange laugh.

93.80.text: Hello, my name is Millie. I'm 10 years old.

100.00.text: I am older now, and I am finding it so hard to learn.

105.12.text: To concentrate. I feel strange sometimes too.

121.74.text: I can't run as fast or climb as high as my friends.

126.12.text: My legs get wobbly and I have to take my medicine.

160.88.text: I really want to be a dancer when I grow up.

164.06.text: But I can't dance now, because of my wobbly legs.

169.32.text: I am not sure what is wrong with me

172.56.text: but I know I am not like the others.

178.32.text: Mummy and Daddy think they gave it to me

186.00.text: But it will be alright when I get better.

189.10.text: They will be happy again, like they used to be.

193.10.text: You'll see, everything will be alright.

198.26.text: Hello, my name is Millie. I am 10yrs old.

203.98.text: I keep coughing when I am eating and drinking

209.76.text: I have to have physiotherapy now, because of my hands

214.04.text: sometimes they do things I don't want them to do.

217.44.text: And I have to have speech therapy too, as they can't tell what I saying.

223.61.text: We have taken blood and done some other tests.

227.46.text: Perhaps how fast the disease is progressing.

232.40.text: Well you have to understand, not many people have heard of this disease. Even doctors.

237.45.text: There are only 80 cases in the UK.

249.16.text: And how are you coping with them?

252.96.text: Well we'll take a look at the medications whilst Millie's here.

257.18.text: And you, how are you coping?

269.58.text: we have to be there for Millie as much as we can.

272.94.text: You need to make your memories now, for the future.

291.94.text: Leave it. You will only upset yourself again.

296.31.text: No, I need to stop being in denial and face this.

305.52.text: There are trials in America, something called cyclodextrin, we could go there.

310.54.text: You know as well as I do the damage done is irreversible.

313.99.text: Maybe so, but they might be able to stop further progression.

330.66.text: How? We can't afford to go to America.

336.31.text: No I only work part time, we can't afford this.

343.50.text: Don't you want to help her?

361.40.text: Life began to get really hard over the next few years.

365.78.text: And Mummy and Daddy got me a wheelchair, because I struggle to walk on my own.

371.98.text: Eating my favourite food is not so much fun anymore

375.82.text: because I keep choking, and it scares Mummy and Daddy.

384.08.text: I used to love to dance and sing

387.26.text: but now I struggle to remember the words.

390.62.text: And I need help with my speech.

395.00.text: Mummy says I can fight anything if I just keep going.

403.52.text: Why is everything becoming so hard?

407.26.text: Each year it feels like I lose another part of me. I can't do the things I used to do.

423.32.text: I went to hospital that day, and life changed for me.

428.52.text: That hospital visit was followed by many more.

433.72.text: Hello, my name is Millie. I'm 10 years old.

441.84.text: I'm older and feel strange most of the time now, not like myself.

449.12.text: Like I am a different girl, not Millie anymore.

513.04.text: Hello, my name is Millie. I'm 10 years old.

548.40.text: 'Are you going to have a fun time?'
